titleInfo.title: Frankie B. Chrisentery oral history interview

mods.abstract: Chrisentery primarily discusses her memories as a student at McKinley High School in the early 1940s. She recalls her favorite teachers, school principals, fellow students, clothing and hair styles, academics, extracurricular activities, shortcomings of the school facilities in the 1940s, and other topics. She discusses some of the prominent graduates and the need to keep the legacy of McKinley High alive. She offers advice to McKinley graduates and contrasts their opportunities against the limited opportunities she faced as a graduate.
mods.note: This collection includes materials accessioned as Mss. 4700.0685; A digital version of the transcript (pdf) exists for duplication purposes; A digital version of the audio recording (mp3) exists for duplication purposes and public access in the Special Collections Reading Room; Interview conducted by Shawnda Hollins.

Frankie B. Chrisentery was born in East Baton Rouge Parish, La. She attended McKinley Senior High School in Baton Rouge, graduating in 1944. She went to Grambling State University, then Southern University for two years each. Chrisentery earned a master's degree from Indiana University and worked for many years as an educator in several East Baton Rouge Parish schools.

physicalDescription.extent: 1 digital audio file (33 minutes); Transcript (22 leaves); Abstract (2 leaves)
